awd_abstract_narration:
The rapid decrease in the cost of solar modules is motivating significant increases in distributed solar generation from rooftops and solar farms.  Since the electric grid was not designed to support large-scale decentralized, intermittent, and uncontrollable solar generation, there are strict caps set on the amount of solar energy that may connect to the grid. Unfortunately, due to rapid solar growth, users are now starting to hit these caps. In addition, setting strict caps is highly inefficient, and wastes much of the grid's potential to accept solar power.  Instead, as in the Internet, all users should be able to freely connect solar modules to the grid and dynamically share its capacity to transmit solar power. The proposal includes hardware in the loop simulation activities that will demonstrate feasibility of the approach.

To address the problem, this project will conduct fundamental research on the design of "smart" software-defined solar (SDS) systems that self-regulate the power they let "flow" into the grid.  Similar to data transmission in the Internet, SDS systems dynamically regulate the solar energy that flows into the grid to maximize its available solar capacity, maintain a balanced supply and demand, and fairly share the available capacity among connected users. In particular, the project will develop new mechanisms for fairly controlling solar power flows, new protocols for rate-limiting solar flows into the grid, and new policies for leveraging batteries as energy buffers to regulate solar flows.   To enable SDS, the project will design new mechanisms for fairly controlling solar output from inverters and charge controllers, new protocols for rate-limiting solar injection into the grid, and new policies for leveraging batteries as energy buffers to regulate solar output.  Collectively, these mechanisms and policies will provide the technical foundation for a new class of "networking" protocols for solar energy.

por.por_cntn:
The rapid decrease in the cost of solar modules is motivating significant increases in distributed solar generation. Since the electric grid was not designed to support large-scale decentralized, intermittent, and uncontrollable solar generation, governments have started placing hard caps on the amount of grid-tied solar capacity. However, users are starting to hit these caps, which is restricting natural growth in solar demand. To address the problem, this award focused on the design of "smart" software-defined solar (SDS) systems that dynamically self-regulate the power they inject into the grid, similar to data in the Internet, to maximize the grid's available solar capacity, maintain grid stability, and fairly share the grid's solar capacity among connected users. By dynamically self-regulating solar power, SDS systems remove the need for statically capping solar systems by policy, instead enabling any SDS system to freely connect to the grid. To enable SDS, the project designed i) new mechanisms for programmatically and fairly controlling solar output in solar power optimizers, ii) new protocols for rate-limiting distributed solar output into the grid, and iii) new policies for leveraging batteries as energy buffers to regulate solar output. The project's foundation was the design and implementation of a new programmable solar power optimizer that enabled fine-grained programmable control of solar power between zero and its maximum power output based on the solar irradiance.  Collectively, these mechanisms and policies provided a technical foundation for a new class of techniques and protocols for dynamically and programmatically regulating distributed solar power.  

The project also had multiple broader impacts beyond the technical contributions above. As part of the project, we publicly released multiple energy datasets and an open-source toolkit for data-driven solar performance modeling and forecasting to enable other researchers to reproduce and extend our work. We also incorporated principles from the project into a graduate course on Green Computing, and provided an introduction, demo, and tutorial on solar energy to the UMass Summer Engineering Institute, an annual summer program to introduce high school students to engineering fields. The project supported two Ph.D. students that accepted tenure-track faculty positions at other Universities after graduation. Finally, the project also worked with the UMass Energy Extension, which provides technical guidance to small towns to reduce their carbon footprint, to apply some of the project's research in practice.
